title: High-resolution mapping of mitotic DNA synthesis under conditions of replication stress in cultured cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Cell culture for MiDAS-seq
Timing: 1–2 weeks
During this step, previously optimized conditions are used to synchronize cells at the G1/S transition, release cells into S-phase in the presence of RO-3306 and aphidicolin, and subsequently release them again into mitosis in the presence of EdU (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E). Mitotic cells thus prepared have incorporated EdU at MiDAS sites and are collected by mitotic shake-off.
Note: The incorporation of EdU in mitotic cells can be confirmed by preparing cells for detection of mitotic EdU foci by fluorescent microscopy.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1],2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2],7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]
Seed 1.25 × 106 H1299 cells per T175 flask (15 flasks per condition).
Note: The number of flasks to use depends on the number of mitotic cells recovered in previous optimization sections. We recommend aiming for at least 106 mitotic cells per experiment.
Place cells in the incubator for 48 h.
Treat cells with 1.5 mM thymidine.
Place cells in the incubator for 16 h.
Wash cells with three times with 10 mL PBS.
Add 12 mL pre-warmed culture medium per flask supplemented with 6 μM RO-3306 and 0.2 μM aphidicolin.
Place cells in the incubator for 10.5 h.
Critical: The duration and dose of aphidicolin treatment should delay S phase progression without preventing mitotic entry. The duration and dose of RO-3306 treatment should ensure that the cells are reversibly arrested in G2.
Note: Here, low-dose aphidicolin treatment is used to slow down replication fork progression. Cells carrying certain genetic alterations (e.g., BRCA2 gene inactivation) also exhibit slow replication fork progression. The protocols above should be optimised accordingly for cells of each genotype.
Treat cells with 2 mM hydroxyurea.
Place cells in the incubator for 1.5 h.
Wash cells three times with 5–10 mL pre-warmed culture medium supplemented 2 mM hydroxyurea.

Critical: The total duration of the washes should not exceed 5 min.
Add 12 mL pre-warmed culture medium per flask supplemented with 2 mM hydroxyurea, 100 ng/mL nocodazole and 10 μM EdU.
Place cells in the incubator for 1.5 h.
Perform a mitotic shake-off (e.g., gently tap the flask against a hard surface or with the hand) to detach the loosely attached mitotic cells, without lifting interphase cells. Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9].
Note: Adapt the strength of the mitotic shake-off to each cell line. For example, H1299 cells reaching mitosis tend to stick to the flask, therefore a stronger shake-off is required. If many mitotic cells still remain attached, then the number of flasks should be increased.
Collect the medium containing floating mitotic cells in 50-mL tubes.
Centrifuge cells at 300 × g for 5 min.
Wash cells with PBS and transfer to one 15-mL tube per condition.
Centrifuge cells at 300 × g for 5 min.
Resuspend cell pellets in 1 mL PBS. Make sure to obtain a single-cell solution by pipetting up and down several times.
Vortex cell solution at low speed and add ice-cold methanol, dropwise, to a final concentration of 90% (v/v).
Place fixed cells on ice for at least 1 h.
Pause point: The cells can be stored at −20°C up to several months.
Cell permeabilization and the ‘click’ reaction
Timing: 3 h
During this step, a cleavable biotin-azide is crosslinked to the EdU-labeled DNA using ‘click’ chemistry.
Note: The protocol below is adapted from Macheret and Halazonetis.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]
Centrifuge cells at 350 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Wash cell pellets with 3 mL of ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge cells at 350 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Resuspend cell pellets in 1 mL permeabilization buffer per 3 × 106 cells.

Incubate the cell suspension at room temperature for 30 min.
Centrifuge cells at 350 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Wash cells with 3 mL of PBS.
Centrifuge cells at 350 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Note: Ensure that pipet tips are not contaminated with 2-β-mercaptoethanol or dithiothreitol (DTT), as this would cleave the biotin-azide and thus prevent binding of the EdU-labelled DNA to the streptavidin beads.
Prepare the biotin-azide ‘click’ reaction cocktail according to the table above (see materials and equipment[href=https://www.wicell.org#materials-and-equipment]). Prepare 250 μL per 3 × 106 cells.
Resuspend cell pellets in 250 μL of biotin-azide click reaction cocktail per 3 × 106 cells.
Incubate cell suspensions for 30 min at room temperature and in the dark.
Centrifuge cells at 350 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Wash cells in 3 mL PBS.
Isolation of EdU-labeled DNA
Timing: 3–5 days
During this step, DNA is purified and fragmented using sonication. Next, the EdU-labeled DNA is isolated using streptavidin beads that bind to the EdU biotinylated in the previous protocol. Finally, EdU-labeled DNA is prepared for next-generation sequencing.
Centrifuge cells at 350 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Resuspend cells in 400 μL lysis buffer.
Transfer cells to a 1.5 mL tube.
Incubate samples in a water bath at 50°C for at least 3 h.
Pause point: The samples can be incubated overnight at 50°C.
Add 1 volume (400 μL) of phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1). Mix by flicking and transfer to a new 1.5 mL tube.
Incubate for 5 min at room temperature.
Spin in a microcentrifuge at maximum speed for 5 min, at room temperature.
Recover the aqueous phase and transfer to a new 1.5-mL tube.
Add 1 volume (400 μL) of chloroform/isoamyl alcohol. Mix by inverting.

Spin in a microcentrifuge at maximum speed for 5 min at room temperature.
Recover the aqueous phase (taking care not to touch the interphase) and transfer to a new 1.5-mL tube.
Add NaCl to a final concentration of 0.2 M (16 μL of 5 M NaCl). Mix well.
Add 1 μL of glycogen as carrier.
Precipitate the DNA by adding 2 volumes (832 μL) of ice-cold ethanol.
Incubate for 2 h at −20°C.
Pause point: The samples can be kept at −20°C for several months.
Centrifuge at maximum speed for 30 min at 4°C.
Aspirate and discard the supernatants. Be careful not to disrupt the pellets.
Wash with 70% ice-cold ethanol.
Spin in a micro-centrifuge at maximum speed for 15 min at 4°C.
Aspirate and discard the supernatants. Be careful not to disrupt the pellets.
Let the pellet dry for 5 min at room temperature.
Add 55 μL TE buffer.
Let the DNA resuspend at room temperature for several hours.
Pause point: The samples can be left at room temperature overnight or stored at −20°C for up to several months.
Measure the DNA concentration using a Qubit fluorometer with dsDNA BR assay kit.
Transfer 5–15 μg of DNA to a new 1.5-mL tube. Adjust the volume to 105 μL with water.
Note: If the starting material is lower, proceed with as much DNA as possible.
Optional: Retrieve 5 ng DNA to be used as a chromatin input sample to generate baseline for the sequencing profiles.
Use a bioruptor to sonicate the DNA into fragments of 100–500 bp.

Critical: The bioruptor settings should be optimized to obtain DNA fragments of 250 bp in length (range 100–500 bp). The size of the DNA fragments can be checked on an agarose gel. For instance, chromatin was sheared for 6 sonication cycle (15 s ON /90 s OFF) using a bioruptor PICO from Diagenode. Note that efficiency of the sonication depends on the type of tube used.
Run 2 μL of sonicated DNA on a 1% agarose gel and assess the length of DNA fragment using gel imaging system.
Resuspend the Dynabeads MyOne Streptadvin C1 beads in the vial by vortexing.
Transfer 50 μL of bead suspension in one 1.5-mL tube per sample.
Place the tube on the magnet for 1–2 min. Carefully aspirate and discard the preservative solution while the tube is on the magnet. It is essential not to let the beads dry.
Remove the tube from the magnet and wash the beads with 50 μL of 1×BW buffer.
Resuspend the beads by vortexing at low speed and perform a short spin (1,000 × g, 20°C, 5 s).
Place the tube on the magnet for 1–2 min. Carefully aspirate and discard the supernatants while the tube is on the magnet.
Repeat the washing steps two more times.
Resuspend the beads in 100 μL 2×BW buffer.
Transfer 100 μL of beads to a new 1.5-mL tube. Add 100 μL of sonicated DNA.
Incubate the samples for 15 min at room temperature on a rotating wheel to allow the binding of the EdU-labeled DNA.
Place the tube on the magnet for 1–2 min. Carefully aspirate and discard the supernatants while the tube is on the magnet.
Remove the tube from the magnet and wash the beads with 200 μL of 1×BW buffer.

Resuspend the beads by vortexing at low speed and perform a short spin (1,000 × g, 20°C, 5 s).
Place the tube on the magnet for 1–2 min. Carefully aspirate and discard the supernatants while the tube is on the magnet.
Repeat the washing steps two more times.
Remove the tube from the magnet and wash the beads with 200 μL of TE.
Resuspend the beads by vortexing at low speed and perform a short spin (1,000 × g, 20°C, 5 s).
Place the tube on the magnet for 1–2 min. Carefully aspirate and discard the supernatants while the tube is on the magnet.
Remove the tube from the magnet and add 55 μL of elution solution (2-β-mercaptoethanol).
Resuspend the beads by pipetting.
Incubate for 1 h at room temperature.
Place the samples on the magnet for 1–2 min. Recover the supernatants, which contains the eluted EdU-labeled DNA, while the tube is on the magnet. Transfer to a new 1.5-mL tube.
Measure the DNA concentration with a Qubit fluorometer with dsDNA BR assay kit using 5 μL of each sample.
Critical: At this point, you may not be able to quantify the chipped DNA. However, you can still process to the library preparation and use as much DNA as you have.
Pause point: The samples can be stored at −20°C for days.
Use 5 ng of eluted DNA to prepare sequencing libraries according to the manufacturer’s instructions (TruSeq ChIP Library Preparation Kit, Illumina).
Perform high-throughput 100-bp single-end sequencing using an Illumina Hi-Seq 4000 sequencer, aiming for at least 20 × 106 reads per sample.
Optional: Perform the library preparation and high-throughput sequencing steps for the chromatin input samples as well.
